title: What are some good examples of self introduction paragraphs? - Quora

response.answer_text: “CRASH! The Steinway smashed to the ground a scant yard from Henry’s head, spearing lances of shattered wood and deadly shards of blasted metal through the air. Henry lurched back, impacting the wall hard enough to knock the breath out of him. What did the angry piano dealer, Jasper, really want? Was One-Eye’s strange message credible, or even comprehensible? And could he really trust the sweet-eyed librarian, Jane Russell, who smiled just maybe a little too urgently? One thing the policeman-turned-piano-tuner knew: things were never going to be the same.” I don’t write this sort of stuff. But you get the idea. What the hell is going on here? Do you want people to turn a page over to get at least some of the answers? Well, give them a clue: maybe a search for Jasper, whose studio has suddenly disappeared for some reason. Is Jane an allied secret agent or an enemy agent… or just a librarian? Is One-Eye a dissident looking for sanctuary, a disguised allied agent, or an enemy operator looking to confuse and trap the man who had killed his brother? Or was he really only the deluded lollipop-seller on the corner of Carter Street and Church Lane that he appeared? If you are hoping to sell a manuscript to a publisher for the first time, you have to go through the slush-pile. The copy editor has thousands of books to read. If yours doesn't grab-grab-GRAB at least for a few pages, he or she is going to drop it in the trashcan if it doesn’t make them want to read on. Make the copy editor WANT to know what’s on the next page. Trim unneeded words: excess adjectives (come on, we’ve all done it, including me. Adverbs, too.) ANY WORDS THAT DON’T ADD TO THE STORY, DELETE! “I did,” she blushed. “What?” he blurted. “Come on,” he snarled. “Where am I?” he bleared. WHAT? Have you ever heard of “show, don’t tell”? Do you know what it means? Every time you stop to say, “she said”, or “it was really great” or “Freida's team won” as prose, you are yanking the reader out of what should feel like a movie to the reader. Imagine all these sorts of words are narrative: it would annoy you after a while. You can’t avoid “Mary said” or the like sometimes, but please, keep it to that. Mary blushed. “Who told you that?” works better than, ‘“Who told you that?” Mary blushed’, because “Mary blushed” as a statement is something the main character can see, rather than a strange new vowel you, the reader, have to imagine. Your first paragraph MUST want the copy editor to want to read to the second page, then on to the third, and so on. Above all, just WRITE. Maybe people will love your first book. Maybe they won’t. That doesn’t make you a failed writer: just a writer. I was spoiled by having my first book published: that’s not bragging. I now have a meme based on my first two books: L. H. Franzibald. Thanks, guys. I has arrived. To paraphrase Rocky Horror with regard to editors: “I didn’t MAKE him for you!”

“Her tits were hanging out again. He watched her bikini spilling its baubles as she breast-stroked across the artificial lagoon. He laughed to himself. A crude thought crossed his pristine mind, interrupting a career move he’d been plotting. He grabbed his towel and headed off for a cold morning shower.” A Fever in Paradise - Ruth Hessey What makes a good opening paragraph? You have to grab the reader’s attention, catapult them to the heights of interest in order for them to read it and KEEP reading. Use humour, intrigue, vividness, drama, slapstick, whatever, or a hybrid of these, to achieve it. It’s like an audition for drama school. You have to be good in the first ten seconds or you’re out. Or a cover letter for a job interview. You have to grab the employer’s interest in the first sentence/paragraph to put you in the “yes” pile. Don’t stuff around. Be bold, have flair, be felicitous. Pique interest, curiosity. As Billy Wilder said, “You gotta grab ‘em by the throat and never let ‘em go.”
